captions.text: For me, it's like a dream come true.
I could have sworn it was heaven.
It's the place where dreams come true.
You want to have a catch?

title: A Catch With Dad - Field of Dreams (9/9) Movie CLIP (1989) HD

comments.text:
"You ever hold a ball or a glove to your face?" - Shoeless Joe

2:20 Ray holds both with his first catch with his father in 20 years﻿
comments.author: MAC 1

comments.text: That moment when Ray looks at his glove! Water works﻿

comments.text: crying like a pussy﻿

comments.author: Yellow4494

comments.text: Holy mother of feels.﻿
comments.author: jms21y

comments.text: The feels. Everytime. ﻿
comments.author: Mike Wilk

comments.text:
Lost my dad when I was 14 now I am 48 and I still wish I could have a catch 
with him, just one more time. I have played pro ball but nothing will ever 
take the place of a catch with my dad. Tomorrow is the anniversary of his 
death. 4/4/81. I will always love you.﻿
comments.author: Gehrig Taylor

comments.text:
I weep like a little school girl when he says, "Hey...Dad? You wanna have a 
catch?".﻿
comments.author: radconserv68

comments.text: money they have..and peace they lack﻿
comments.author: James Laskowski

comments.text:
It took a few viewings, but I finally got the emphasis on their last 
handshake. It's a really long one that encompasses a thousand unsaid 
apologies between the two of them. Like a "Please....don't let go."  We men 
just have a hard time with our words at times.  Say what you have to say to 
those who matter before it's too late.  Not all of us live in Iowa.﻿
comments.author: Bob K.

comments.text:
As men most of us don't talk about stuff like that. But the bond between a 
father and son is eternal. Don't need to say touchy feely shit to know that 
and this scene shows why. Never really got along with my old man but he 
stuck around and we always had baseball as a shared love. Sometimes a catch 
is just a catch, but looking back decades later it goes down as a memory to 
treasure.
comments.author: TheSeattlehawk94

comments.text:
And that's the game..... as I said in a different response, my dad and I 
didn't have a great relationship when I was growing up. We finally "found" 
a friend in each other late in my father's life after I had children of my 
own. That handshake was like our finding each other -- no words of apology 
were really needed. They were said X10 by our relationship from that point 
on.
comments.author: Terry Headley

comments.text: ?????? was that supposed to make me cry﻿

comments.text: And the tears fall beautiful ﻿

comments.text:
My dad died when I was seventeen years old. I'd give anything to share a

comments.author: Ian Anderson

comments.text:
My father might not have brought me up with baseball, and I made my way to 
all state, but I will tell everyone......I will find a field and throw an

comments.text: There was a bucket full in front of me.
comments.author: Frankincensed

comments.text: It never fails. It's a weird coincidence I guess. Yeah, that's it.
comments.author: radconserv68

comments.text: Heavenly!  ﻿
comments.author: HeavenReservation

comments.text:
In my opinion this is one of the greatest movie's ever made.   Yes it's 
about baseball, father's and sons and dreams but it's primarily about 
second chances.  All of us can relate to that and for most of us who are 
getting older and have lost our dads this scene still resonates 25 years 
later.  I lost my dad when I was a teenager.  Miss him every single day of 
my life.  I can still hear him sharing his words of wisdom with me.   I 
wish he could see his grand daughter and I wish we could have one more 
catch. ﻿
comments.author: DD Sara

comments.text:
This scene gets me everytime, it bring great memories with my dad. I'll 
always remember when he said to me, "Always keep your faith with God, and 
let that faith be strong enough to reach for your goals. Dreams will come 
true, If you believe in yourself, you'll get it."

He died while I was still in college, October 18, 2007. 

He was so only 48, so young.﻿
comments.author: RoCk'In RoLl AlIeN from Japan

comments.text:
+Manoa Maloata Thank you Manoa for your very tender reflection. My dad died 
when I was 16 years of age - too young to know anything about mortality, 
and when we find out it is too late. The final scene always gets me... I 
would have given anything to have had another opportunity to play catch 
with my dad. It is one of those 'what if' moments we carry with us until we 
(hopefully) get another chance at it.
comments.author: A Cazzoli

comments.text: +Manoa Maloata I feel you. <:')
comments.author: Ben Schubert

comments.text: Gets me every time﻿
comments.author: WillyM79

comments.text:
My dad beat my stepmom, threw me out of the house when I was 16, was a 
major drug addict and stole my college tuition fund to feed his habit, gave 
my car to his girlfriend, (which I paid for by working summer and after 
school jobs) When I had to join the Navy instead of going to college. And 
of course, she wrecked it....
My father taught me that you can rely on no one but yourself. And that only 
I can make my dreams come true through hard work. That was the only 
valuable thing he taught me. My father was a power of example - of how not 
to be. Thanks dad! Rest in peace!﻿

comments.author: GoldenGateNum9

comments.text:
My Dad isn't the greatest Dad in the world. He drank, cheated on my mom and 
is a workaholic. That being said, he always made sure we never went 
without, always had food and a roof over our heads and taught me two 
valuable lessons.
1. If you want anything in life you have to work for it, anyone who gives 
you something for free has an agenda.
2. It takes a piss poor excuse of a man to beat on a woman.

He's never been perfect, but he is a good Dad.
comments.author: petis1976

comments.text:
My pops wasn't the greatest either. He rather spend his time at the bars 
than with his only son. Because of that I never learned basic boy stuff 
like throwing a baseball....my wife and I are now expecting our first 
child, a boy. It's a bit humiliating and I am swallowing my pride, but at 
38, I'm hiring a pitching coach to teach me how to throw a decent ball, so 
in a few years, I can teach my own son.

comments.text:
The best memory I have of my father, and there are plenty of them (he was a 
wise and gentle man), was one night I decided to visit him and my mother 
and I fell asleep watching movies with them. I woke up to him patting my 
hand and smiling at me. 

He passed on January 9th 2006, at 4 30 in the morning. 

Love you father. ﻿

comments.author: Matthew Roseborough

comments.text:
@Yzurri-   yeah, this scene totally gets me chocked up.  Playing catch with 
your father is sort of like a rite of passage to becoming a young man, it's 
that incredible bonding moment between father and son.  My father did that 
with me and I've done it with both of my sons and I will forever cherish 
those moments in my life, those are priceless moments.  Just a word of 
advice, it's never too late to become the "Dad" of your children, no matter 
the age or the distance, or the lapse of time since you saw one another, 
don't let it go, re-attach that love and inner peace with them. Peace.
comments.author: Joe Figueroa

comments.text:
+Terry Headley

But to say that none would is simply stupid.
comments.author: CameronDiazTwin

comments.text:
+Terry Headley
Spent many a summer at the ball park (Busch Stadium, don't hate me!) with 
my dad.

he also coached me on my team that made it to williamsports pa for the 
LLWS. almost insulting that women think they get it to the depth we do. 
shows an inferiority complex that they feel compelled to say get everything 
about men. no man would claim that about women.
comments.author: Yzurri

comments.text:
+Terry Headley
Exactly. You get it.
comments.author: Yzurri

comments.text:
+Terry Headley +Suzanne Weisbecker Oh, and I almost forgot the most 
important part. About the only thing my dad and I shared growing up was a 
love of baseball and of the Cincinnati Reds "Big Red Machine" of the 1970s. 
Let me ask you, recite the starting line up of any baseball team from 40 
years ago? I can, and I would bet a lot of the guys on this comments page 
can. I can also literally still smell the new mown grass and the freshly 
oiled leather glove. I can still close my eyes and see the beautiful blue 
sky. I can still taste the dirt in my mouth and hear the sound of a 
fastball slamming into my catcher's mitt. And I can still feel the hand of 
my father on my shoulder when I sat down in the dugout between innings. 
Perhaps you did have a similar experience. My guess (admittedly only my 
guess) is you that you didn't.
comments.author: Terry Headley

comments.text:
+Suzanne Weisbecker If you DID understand you wouldn't be arguing the 
point. The point is not the bonding over a game of catch, it is the sense 
of recovering something that was thought lost forever. It is, in essence, 
redemption. I had a bad relationship with my dad while I was growing up. He 
was a good man, but having lost his own father at age eight, he never had 
anyone to serve as a role model. I was the oldest and, in essence, the 
guinea pig. 
We never bonded until much later in life after I had my own children. I was 
lucky enough to "find" my father before he died. We had several great years 
as 'friends." And that is something I cherish. 
Now, my wife loves the movie, but she doesn't "get" the scene and why it 
reverberates so much in a male heart. I am sure there are some women who 
do, but it does seem to be a "guy" thing, much like there are movies that 
are "chick flicks." Doesn't make anyone inferior or superior, just 
recognizes something we all know and that is that in general men and women 
are wired differently.
comments.author: Terry Headley

comments.author: PennHoo

comments.text:
Not true, I am my father's daughter...I was told all my life that when I 
was a baby girl, I was the light of my dad's life but for me growing up, I 
never seemed to measure up to that story.  Even as an adult I questioned 
whether or not I was his child. So when I saw this movie, I was an 
uncontrollable mess of sobs. I remember being a little girl & having my 
little toolbox just like my dad's but then as I grew older, felt pushed 
away by him...so far away I didn't feel like his child. It has taken me a 
lifetime to understand his life, my life & the 'why' of it all. But will 
tell you as soon as this movie started to unfold, I began to cry but 
understood all the 'tiny' nuances in this movie that I believe is 'life on 
earth & life in heaven.' Long story short, my dad & I pieced & patched our 
lives at the same time... his with memories of his unhappy childhood 
lacking his father physically & emotionally & me with him, lacking his 
attention & approval. I now know I my dad loved me all along....just a very 
ill person standing between him & me. So it's not just a son & father 
thing... it's a child & parent thing...& today I would love to have a game 
of catch with my dad...........   just my life that's all...no harm, no 
foul..............

I posted this video on Facebook for my dad on Father's Day. I could tell he 
loved it before I went over to see him. We use to play catch all the time

we had a game of catch. I used that exact line when I grabbed our gloves. 
It was a great day.﻿

Remember the last time my daddy saw this movie, he cried in this moment and

comments.author: TheJACKCOLORADO

comments.text:
I know that for Americans, baseball means a lot. I'm a Brit with no 
interest in the game, but this film makes me weep uncontrollably. I see the 
baseball as a symbol of what brings fathers and sons together, and how 
important it is that parents spend time with their children, time being the 
most precious thing a parent and child can give each other, after love.﻿
comments.author: cbak12sg

comments.text:
I've actually wondered how somebody without baseball as a fixture in their 
culture would react to a baseball film (there are a lot) and this one 
specifically.  Being a Canadian myself, baseball is not quite as strong 
culturally here but it's very present.  I'm glad to see what makes the 
movie and baseball special isn't lost to those with little to no exposure 
to the game

comments.text:
I may or may not suffer from allergy-induced watery eyes each time I see 
the following parts of these movies:

"Tell me I've had a good life. Tell me I'm a good man." - old Matt Damon, 
Saving Private Ryan

"She was never mine to keep" - Wolverine, Les Miserables (I make it a good, 
what, 2:55 with +LM Stewart sobbing next to me before that line finally 
does me in, which is I think pretty good, and also highly manly)

"Hey Dad? You want to have a catch?" - Crash Davis, Field of Dreams 
(allergies are always about DEFCON-3 by the time this line comes out; must 
be Iowa grass)

"A toast to my big brother George: The richest man in town!" Harry Bailey, 
It's a Wonderful Life. Just like everybody reading this!

Those few minutes of Up.
﻿

comments.text:
Those few minutes of Up do it to me no matter how many times I watch. I 
swear, the cats know just when to sit right by my head and swish their 
dander-filled tails.
comments.author: Cailín “Little Bit Fae” MacKay

comments.text:
Brings back so many memories of.catching with my dad, those the best times 
and it.brings me so.much tears and smiles to.see the ending every time:)﻿
comments.author: unstablerooster

comments.text: Every... damn... time... *tears*﻿
comments.author: Mst3kfan1994

comments.text: Me too bro, don't worry bout it
comments.author: John Lysaght

comments.text: it's like they're in the 1956﻿
comments.author: Jacorey Harris

comments.text: Yea I had something in my eye lol﻿
comments.author: Ants250

comments.text:
My dad is past 50. He has a lot of back problems. It hurts for him to toss 
a baseball or football, but there's nothing he loves more than doing it 
with me. I have no brothers, which makes him all the more valuable to me. ﻿
comments.author: Gordontrek

comments.text:
My dad was the same way. I was born when he was 48. But he hung around til 
I was about 20. He passed a few months ago at 71. What I wouldn't give to 
play catch one last time...
comments.author: Luke Greenly

comments.text: Excuse me I have something in my eye....﻿
comments.author: Elias Toufexis

comments.text: This is one of my all-time favorites.
comments.author: Simona Winslow

comments.text: Me, too. I love this movie
comments.author: Sandra SUE

comments.text: So do I.
comments.author: Gumball LastRally

comments.text:
Is "have a catch" a regional term?  I've never heard it outside of this 
movie.﻿
comments.author: jwmellott

comments.text: +Bill Tidy Yes, we said "play catch"  too, not "have a catch".(Indiana0
comments.author: Jeff Mellott

comments.text: Kevin Costner thought it was weird too.
comments.author: SCE2AUX2

comments.text:
i am from ILLinois, which is next to Iowa and we would say "do you want to 
play catch:" in the form of a question. So the dialogue is realistid
comments.author: Bill Tidy

comments.text: maybe, i'm from iowa and it sounds normal to me.
comments.author: John Nolan

comments.text:
Like so many American men, I seem to have a strange allergy to this scene. 
Every single time I see it, my nose stuffs up & my eyes begin to water 
uncontrollably.﻿

Spend Time with your Children I know its hard with work and the Hustle 
Bustle of life. But would you rather let the streets get them and spend 
time visiting them in PRISON ?????﻿
comments.author: Gary Stevens (Christians care)

comments.text:
Same reaction......I was 28 when the movie came out. Now that I'm 52 and 
worn down by life, this gets me every time. The other scene that gets me 
here is "hey rookie, you were good."
comments.author: JGG11

comments.text: Don`t make them like this anymore.
comments.author: ThatGuyThatWearsSuperheroT-Shirts

comments.text:
This whole movie hits me in that soft spot a great american classic film 
.They don't make them like this anymore .This is a movie that current film 
makers could learn from.You don't need to be sophisticated or over 
complicated to seem intellectual or artsy fartsy .You just need to tell a 
great story its that simple .Great storytelling at its finest .
comments.author: JAY OH

comments.text:

time visiting them in PRISON ?????﻿

comments.text:
A strong father figure establishes men. My boys have hated me along the way 
but they respect and admire me at the same time. They know I stand on Solid 
Ground.

comments.text:

Dad,Tony. He will not always be around. Have a catch with him from me too.

comments.text:
My dad was always with me except when I was a baby he was always with his 
friends he an my mom fight a lot and I had go to my granny's house when 
they argued I would cry myself to sleep every night when I was a kid
